repolarization and now we're talking
about the last phase hyper-polarization
and where we ended off in the last
episode potassium was rushing out this
cell because voltage-gated potassium ion
channels opened and potassium wanted to
leave so potassium is now gone now
potassium as it's going out of the cell
it's trying to reach its equilibrium
potential which is somewhere around
negative 93 millivolts
now the resting member membrane
potential is somewhere around negative
70 millivolts so we're going lower than
that resting membrane potential and that
part that process is called hyper
polarization in other words it's over
polarized it's overshooting the resting
membrane potential and going even more
negative towards the equilibrium
potential for potassium because that's
where potassium wants to be no once we
start heading towards that really
negative negative 93 millivolts there's
a another process that's still happening
in the background and that's the sodium
potassium pump is still doing its work
if you remember what that is from the
episode where we spoke about the
channels in the membrane the proteins in
the membrane the sodium potassium pumps
three sodium ions out and it pumps two
potassium ions in and what that does as
it's working is it brings that membrane
potential right back around the resting
membrane potential and that's the end of
the action potential so we have
depolarization or repolarization
hyper-polarization and then the sodium
potassium pump doing its job to bring it
